title: 107_hr4231
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Advocacy Improvement Act of 2002". Congress finds that excessive regulations burden small businesses, with federal agencies imposing disproportionate regulations. An independent office of small business advocacy is needed to ensure agencies are responsive and compliant with statutory obligations. The office must be independent to effectively advocate for small businesses without being influenced by other agencies. An independent office of small business advocacy is essential for conducting economic studies, maintaining databases, and assessing the impact of regulations on small businesses. The office will provide valuable information and advice to Congress and federal agencies, ensuring statutory independence and adequate financial resources. The proposed entity aims to advocate for small businesses, report to relevant committees and the Small Business Administration, secure separate funding, and enhance the role of the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman. The proposed entity aims to advocate for small businesses and enhance the role of the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman through greater cooperation with the Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. The proposed entity aims to advocate for small businesses and enhance the role of the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman through greater cooperation with the Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration. SEC. 3. APPOINTMENT OF CHIEF COUNSEL OF ADVOCACY. In General, Section 201 of Public Law 94-305 is amended to establish the management of the Office in a Chief Counsel for Advocacy appointed by the President. The Chief Counsel must be appointed without regard to political affiliation and should be fit for the role. Individuals who have served in the Small Business Administration in the past 5 years are ineligible for the position. The Chief Counsel's salary should not exceed a certain rate. The Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration shall be paid at a rate not exceeding level III of the Executive Schedule. After a President's term ends, the Chief Counsel may serve for up to one year until a successor is nominated. The incumbent Chief Counsel will continue in their position as per Public Law 94-305. SEC. 4. PRIMARY FUNCTIONS OF OFFICE OF ADVOCACY. Section 202 of Public Law 94-305 (15 U.S.C. 634b) is amended to expand assistance to small business concerns owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals, women, and veterans. Section 202 of Public Law 94-305 (15 U.S.C. 634b) is amended to expand assistance to small businesses owned and controlled by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals, women, and veterans. The amendments include changes such as striking certain paragraphs, redesignating others, and making recommendations to the President and relevant committees. The Chairmen and Ranking Members of the House and Senate Small Business Committees, along with the Small Business Administration Administrator, address issues and regulations affecting small businesses, calling for corrective action by Federal agencies or Congress. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL FUNCTIONS. In General, Section 203 of Public Law 94-305 is amended to include additional functions for the Office of Advocacy, such as maintaining economic databases, carrying out responsibilities of the Chief Counsel, and entering into a memorandum of understanding with the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman. The Office of Advocacy will cooperate with the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman and provide appropriation estimates to relevant committees and the Office of Management and Budget. The President's budget must include a separate statement of appropriations requested for the Office of Advocacy. SEC. 6. DEPUTY CHIEF COUNSELS AND REGIONAL ADVOCATES. Section 204 of Public Law 94-305 (15 U.S.C. 634d) is amended to allow the Chief Counsel to appoint 2 Deputy Chief Counsels with a pay rate not exceeding level III of the Senior Executive Service. Additionally, regional advocates may be appointed within each Standard Federal Region to assist in examining the role of small businesses. The Chief Counsel can appoint 2 Deputy Chief Counsels with a pay rate not exceeding level III of the Senior Executive Service. Regional advocates may be appointed to assist in examining the role of small businesses in the economy of the United States and represent their views before Federal agencies. They also coordinate with the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman to assist regional small business fairness boards and disseminate information about Federal Government programs and services. The Chief Counsel can appoint Deputy Chief Counsels to assist in examining the role of small businesses in the economy and represent their views before Federal agencies. Regional advocates coordinate with the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman to disseminate information about Federal Government programs and services. The Chief Counsel assigns duties to carry out the mission of the Office of Advocacy. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will provide the Office of Advocacy with necessary office space, equipment, supplies, and personnel for its operation. Additionally, reports are required. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

The Chief Counsel is required to submit annual reports on agency compliance with title 5, United States Code to various committees and the Small Business Administration Administrator. The Chief Counsel may also prepare and publish other reports as deemed appropriate.

SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 9. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 207 of Public Law 94-305 is amended to increase appropriations to $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, $12,000,000 for fiscal year 2004, and $14,000,000 for fiscal year 2005. (a) Executive Pay Schedule amended in Title 5, United States Code by adding Chief Counsel for Advocacy, Small Business Administration to section 5314 and striking it from section 5315. 
(b) Rural Tourism Training Program amended in Section 311 of the Small Business Administration Reauthorization and Amendments Act of 1990 by replacing "Chief Counsel for Advocacy" with "Administrator". 
(c) Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman amended in Section 30(b)(2) of the Small Business Act by adjusting subparagraphs (D) and (E). In Section 30(b)(2) of the Small Business Act, the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman is required to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the Office of Advocacy for cooperation. The Small Business Act requires cooperation between the Small Business and Agriculture Regulatory Enforcement Ombudsman and the Office of Advocacy. The bill was passed by the House of Representatives on May 21, 2002.
